Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Geopolymeric Nanocomposite, A Next Generation Material For Infrastructure Sustainability

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The major objective of this study is to develop an inexpensive, ecologically sound, high-performance, cementlike construction material ?geopolymeric hybrid composite through nanoengineering the fly ash particles. This new material consists of fly ash based geopolymer matrix and carbon nanotubes (CNTs). To avoid the difficulty of dispersing CNTs, CNTs will be directly grown on the surfaces of fly ash using a novel microwave irradiation method. The cost of CNTs produced by this method is estimated much lower than any other existing methods. A comprehensive testing plan using advanced analytical instruments will be carried out to exam the interaction between nanotubes and the geopolymeric matrix, the reaction kinetics, and the multi-functionality of the new material. This research will be conducted through the close collaboration between two major research universities in Alabama, the University of Alabama and Auburn University. Auburn University will focus on the development of microwave irradiation method. The University of Alabama will manufacture and characterize the proposed new materials.

The proposed work, if succeeds, will generate significant social, economic and environmental benefits. This novel green material meets the requirements of sustainable construction materials with low carbon dioxide emission, long service-life and efficient energy consumption. PIs also propose an aggressive educational plan designed to be complementary to the research activities with focus on recruiting a diverse group of traditionally underrepresented (female, minority and/or socio-economically disadvantaged) students to participate in the proposed activities in close collaboration with HBCUs in Alabama and ALEPSCoR. Results of the proposed research will be widely disseminated.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
A novel ecologically sound, high-performance, cementlike construction material –geopolymeric nanocomposite has been developed in this study. This new material uses carbon nanotubes to reinforce a cementitious material, geopolymer. Unlike ordinary Portland Cement (OPC)-based concrete, geopolymer can be synthesized using industrial waste such as fly ash, and therefore, produces much less carbon dioxide emission than OPC-based concrete does. However, geopolymer is also very brittle as OPC-based concrete. To overcome this drawback, this study invented a new method to reinforce the geopolymer matrix using carbon nanotubes. Carbon nanotubes possess extremely high mechanical properties and excellent electrical and thermal conductivity. Therefore, they cannot only be used to reinforce materials, but also be used to add other functions to the materials. However, it is not only expensive, but also difficult to mix carbon nanotubes into cementitious material such as geopolymer. This study solved this problem by inventing a novel cost-effective method to directly grow carbon nanotubes on the source materials of geopolymer such as fly ash. In this way, carbon nanotubes are self-dispersed in geopolymer with fly ash particles. This new method uses one chemical as both the carbon source and the catalyst for carbon nanotubes, requires very simple equipment, and consumes little energy. The cost of carbon nanotubes obtained by this method is estimated much lower than any other existing methods. Experimental study shows that the nanocomposite produced by this new method is not only stronger, but also possesses self-healing and energy-storage capacities.  This environmentally benign novel green material meets the requirements of future sustainable construction material with low carbon dioxide production, long service-life and efficient energy consumption.

The new method to grow carbon nanotubes on fly ash has also been extended to grow CNTs on other materials, such as carbon fibers. These fibers grown with CNTs can be used to manufacture multifunctional, higher performance structural composites, which can have many application in aerospace structrues, mechanical system, and renewable engergy.

The concept to in-situ produce nanoparticles has been successfully applied to concrete. By using a simple pre-carbonation method through absorbing carbon dioxide gas in calcium rich cementitious materials, calcium carbonate-silica hybrid nano/micro particles can be in-situ produced in fresh concrete, eliminating the major barriors preventing practical application of nanoparticles in construciton materials.

This study also found novel applications of hollow fly ash particles. After acid etching, perforated hollow fly ash particles can be produced, which can be used to store or deliver admixtures in concrete. This will enable a new generation functional concrete.

This project has supported fully or partially 3 PhD students and 2 master students. 5 undergraduate students and 3 high school students have been trained in this project so far. This project has produced one PhD dissertation, nine journal/conference articles, three conference papers/presentations and three patents. Two start-up companies have been established to commercialize the new technologies invented in this project. 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/27/2016
Modified by: Jialai Wang
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: A novel ecologically sound, high-performance, cementlike construction material –geopolymeric nanocomposite has been developed in this study. This new material uses carbon nanotubes to reinforce a cementitious material, geopolymer. Unlike ordinary Portland Cement (OPC)-based concrete, geopolymer can be synthesized using industrial waste such as fly ash, and therefore, produces much less carbon dioxide emission than OPC-based concrete does. However, geopolymer is also very brittle as OPC-based concrete. To overcome this drawback, this study invented a new method to reinforce the geopolymer matrix using carbon nanotubes. Carbon nanotubes possess extremely high mechanical properties and excellent electrical and thermal conductivity. Therefore, they cannot only be used to reinforce materials, but also be used to add other functions to the materials. However, it is not only expensive, but also difficult to mix carbon nanotubes into cementitious material such as geopolymer. This study solved this problem by inventing a novel cost-effective method to directly grow carbon nanotubes on the source materials of geopolymer such as fly ash. In this way, carbon nanotubes are self-dispersed in geopolymer with fly ash particles. This new method uses one chemical as both the carbon source and the catalyst for carbon nanotubes, requires very simple equipment, and consumes little energy. The cost of carbon nanotubes obtained by this method is estimated much lower than any other existing methods. Experimental study shows that the nanocomposite produced by this new method is not only stronger, but also possesses self-healing and energy-storage capacities. This environmentally benign novel green material meets the requirements of future sustainable construction material with low carbon dioxide production, long service-life and efficient energy consumption. The new method to grow carbon nanotubes on fly ash has also been extended to grow CNTs on other materials, such as carbon fibers. These fibers grown with CNTs can be used to manufacture multifunctional, higher performance structural composites, which can have many application in aerospace structrues, mechanical system, and renewable engergy. The concept to in-situ produce nanoparticles has been successfully applied to concrete. By using a simple pre-carbonation method through absorbing carbon dioxide gas in calcium rich cementitious materials, calcium carbonate-silica hybrid nano/micro particles can be in-situ produced in fresh concrete, eliminating the major barriors preventing practical application of nanoparticles in construciton materials. This study also found novel applications of hollow fly ash particles. After acid etching, perforated hollow fly ash particles can be produced, which can be used to store or deliver admixtures in concrete. This will enable a new generation functional concrete. This project has supported fully or partially 3 PhD students and 2 master students. 5 undergraduate students and 3 high school students have been trained in this project so far. This project has produced one PhD dissertation, nine journal/conference articles, three conference papers/presentations and three patents. Two start-up companies have been established to commercialize the new technologies invented in this project. Last Modified: 01/27/2016 Submitted by: Jialai Wang
